> Mattias,
> 
> Ah.  Got it.  What you are talking about is taking the results of a
> long run and turning it into something optimal after you have a
> solution you find desirable.  That makes sense.

Yep, that's it.
 
> It appears we have different goals - yours is after you have done some
> number of NEAT runs and produced a result you then want to exploit in a
> completely separate way (apart from NEAT).  And mine is to further
> reduce the amount of time required *during* a NEAT run so you can get
> to your result more quickly.  These goals are compatible with each
> other.  And with the XML description definitions, it is likely they can
> even be complimentary.

As ken has pointed out, it's rarely the NEAT process that takes time - 
it's almost always the simulation. 

> You wrote:
> 1. The precompiled code would be (slightly) faster.
> 
> I think this is accurate, if you are saying the Delphi dynamic
> evaluation code would be slower than the Delphi pre-compiled code.

I meant a compiled neural network will be faster than traversing the 
nodes and connections. 

> However, you may be saying, precompiled code is faster than
> "interpreted" code.  If this is an accurate view of your statement, I
> would recommend you research the current IBM and Sun JVMs. 

I'll have to take your word for it, because I'm not leaving my Delphi, 
no siree!

with regards,
mattias
